How do you know when an asset price rise has turned into a bubble? In the non-virtual
world, valuation is often a good starting point. A bubble can also be identified by the
steepness and persistence of any price ascent as doubters and naysayers are swept
away in a tidal wave of bullish froth. That is something the main S&P Composite Index
certainly shares with Bitcoin. One justification for the surge in stocks is a profits
recovery. But the underlying profits recovery looks increasingly fragile and indeed on
some key measures a rapid deceleration is underway. With equities over-valued, overbullish
and now also over-bought, the boring old profits cycle still needs watching.

Following the Transaction, Mr John Hornby holds, together with Pippa Hornby, 31,396,512 (19.5 per cent. of the Company's issued share capital). Mr John Hornby completed the Transaction principally to settle personal tax liabilities.

Regrettably, the gross margin weakness was not identified sooner due to an incorrect assessment of the value of the Group's stock. The Group's Financial Controller has resigned as a result of this error. System improvements are being put in place to make sure this issue does not recur.

Company comment that there will be a £3.5m impact to PAT
for 2017. This suggests £4.4m impact on PBT, a 21% shortfall. The company is not guiding yet on 2018, expecting an impact in H1, but normal margins to resume in H2. Depending on the extent of the price increases and any internal actions this would suggest c.15% impact for 2018, note management not changing expectations for revenues. However, we are taking a more cautious 20% off numbers until it is clearer how the margin recovery is progressing.

Sky has concluded an agreement with BT which means Sky customers will have their choice of the best sports all through a single Sky TV subscription, while also broadening the reach of Sky's leading entertainment channel brands to all major Pay-TV services in the UK for the first time.

Under the agreement, Sky will receive wholesale supply of the BT Sport channels enabling it to offer its customers access to every single match of the Premier League, the UEFA Champions League and Europa League shown on Sky and BT channels through one simple Sky contract. This will be the first time Sky is able to provide BT Sport to its customers directly as part of a Sky bundle or on a standalone basis and across all Sky platforms including Sky Go. BT Sport will also be available as an app on NowTV boxes.

Sky will make its NowTV streaming service available on the BT TV set-top-box. As retail agent, BT will sell NowTV on Sky's behalf, offering BT TV customers access to NowTV's most popular content including Sky Atlantic, Sky One, Sky Living, Sky Sports and Sky Cinema.

Over the last quarter BT TV customer growth has grind to a total halt with only a 0.4% qoq growth in Q2 (for a total of only 1.767m customers) at a time of 32% content cost inflation.

...... which led a lot of brokers to spend yesterday afternoon swotting up on Rule 9.1.

Wots Rule 9.1?

BE11:39am

Specifically, rule 8 of Rule 9.1.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

“Occasionally, a person or group of persons acting in concert acquiring shares resulting in a holding of over 50% of the voting rights of a company (which need not be a company to which the Code applies) will thereby acquire or consolidate control, as defined in the Code, of a second company because the first company itself is interested, either directly or indirectly through intermediate companies, in a controlling block of shares in the second company, or is interested in shares which, when aggregated with those which the person or group is already interested in, secure or consolidate control of the second company. The Panel will not normally require an offer to be made under this Rule in these circumstances unless either:

(a) the interest in shares which the first company has in the second company is significant in relation to the first company. In assessing this, the Panel will take into account a number of factors including, as appropriate, the assets, profits and market values of the respective companies. Relative values of 50% or more will normally be regarded as significant; or

(b) securing control of the second company might reasonably be considered to be a significant purpose of acquiring control of the first company.
The Panel should be consulted in all cases which may come within the scope of this Note to establish whether, in the circumstances, any obligation arises under this Rule.”

The upshot of all that is, while Disney probably won't wiggle out of buying Sky from shareholders other than Fox if it ends up with the shares held by Fox and Fox doesn't end up with Sky -- you still following this? -- it theoretically could bail on the deal.

BE11:41am

RBC had an excellent explainer yesterday afternoon.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

There is a presumption, which we agree with, that Disney wants to buy 100% of Sky (Could Fox deliver Sky to the Mouse House? and FOXA: Let's Talk Major Media M&A).

However, one could argue that there are outcomes that could – theoretically at least – allow Disney to take control of Sky via Fox’s 39% stake without paying a premium to the other shareholders. We regard such outcomes as unlikely, but worthy of consideration by investors. Why do we say this?

Ownership of 39% of Sky would arguably allow Disney the same level of control that Fox has had to date. Given the convoluted nature of the bid, there could be potential wriggle room for Fox/Disney to drop the bid (despite the Takeover Panel’s view that the offer still stands). How could this be possible?

The Fox offer for Sky is a pre-conditional offer based on a Scheme of Arrangement. The only remaining pre-condition is regulatory approval. As an example, we see two ways that the offer could lapse:

1) Timetable: The offer has two hard-stop dates: Regulatory approval by August 15th, and the scheme of Arrangement hard stop date of October 15th.
2) Converting the deal to an Offer: Fox made its offer as a Scheme of Arrangement (meaning it would buy 100% of the company subject to 75% approval at a General Meeting at which it is not allowed to vote). However, Fox included in its terms an option to convert the structure from a Scheme of Arrangement to a Takeover Offer. This can be done at any time. Fox could, in theory at least, seek to convert this to an Offer, with whatever minimum threshold it wanted. The key point here is that Fox (or Disney if it controls Fox by this point) is allowed to vote with its shares in a Takeover Offer. It could vote against the deal, blocking the transaction. This would leave Disney with 39% of Sky and the same level of control that Fox has exercised to date. Please note we think this is unlikely as a conversion of the deal from a Scheme to an Offer requires approval from both the independent Sky Board members and the Takeover Panel. We believe the Panel are unlikely to approve such a move.

This is potentially very significant both because of short- and long-term factors. Starting with the long-term factors, the significance of this announcement is that it represents the final push from Sky in making their content available across all platforms in the UK. What this speaks to, in our view, is complete comfort on behalf of Sky in the concept of segmentation – that consumers should be able to access all content, across all platforms either on an ad hoc or contracted basis and that this process can be managed in such a way that it is overall additive to the long-term opportunity at Sky. The market has been skeptical on this point.

BE11:43am

In the short-term, however, the significance is more direct: it potentially signals much less aggressive competition within the FAPL auction process which is due to kick off (forgive the pun) in the new year. That BT and Sky are now carrying each other’s sports channels surely reduces the requirement to push hard for exclusive content including at the forthcoming FAPL auction. For both companies a priori cost inflation expectations are quite high – we forecast 43% inflation for Sky and 25% inflation for BT – this event may suggest these expectations are too conservative.

BE11:43am

Put together, this is a very interesting development which comes at a very interesting time. Broadly we see it potentially drawing a line under what Enders Analysis has called BT’s ‘reign of terror’ as an aggressive competitor for sports and as such a healthy development for the whole market. The question now, of course, is whether new competition is coming in the form of the online players, but this is a debate for another day. We rate Sky as a Buy and BT as a Neutral.

Mitie's recent interim results were disappointing, due principally to weakness in the Property Management and Professional Services divisions. Although management attributed this to one-off factors in both cases, our level of confidence in the achievability of management's target 4.5-5.5% EBITA margin range is diminished, and we downgrade FY18E EPS forecasts by 23%, and FY19-20E by 7-10%. Although the shares trade in-line with the (much de-rated) sector on a PE basis, we believe a 15% discount is merited due to elevated average net debt and lower dividend yield. We cut our price target to 175p and retain our REDUCE recommendation.

Tom Dalgleish @Forrester ask.........Im new to Mitie
BE11:56am

Whilst some elements of CNA’s 23 November profit warning were likely low multiple events, higher competition in North America Business supply and an apparent deterioration in CNA’s competitive position relative to UK Business supply peers threaten to put sustained pressure on earnings. Combined with British Gas Residential (BGR) – where a default tariff price cap is likely to be introduced late 2018 – businesses totalling c.60% of 2016 group NOPAT are at risk of significant LT earnings compression. Based on the PPM price cap methodology, we believe LT (non-PPM) EBIT margins for efficient UK domestic energy retailers of 2-3% are possible post cost cutting, and assume BGR delivers at the top of this range. However, earnings under this base case imply a 30% cut to DPS from the 2018 final divi is likely required to return medium-term divi cover to CNA’s 1.3-1.4x of 2014-16. A divi cut of this magnitude may alleviate the need to raise equity to defend CNA’s BBB+ rating, though some risk remains with credit metrics still modestly below current hurdles to 2020 on our estimates. We cut our PT from 215p to 150p; updating forecasts for current guidance, updated UK retail price cap assumptions, a lower capacity payment price outlook, and wholesale energy prices. We see a numerous factors which are likely to overhang the stock for the next c.12 months, thereby limiting scope for a positive re-rating. We see little reason for investors to take on these headwinds, though most seem to be fairly reflected in the stock price – we thus remain cautious, but EW for now.

12:05 pm
BE12:05pm

Clearly this was a very challenging quarter for H&M, following a promising start. The company states that sales online and for the smaller brands developed well but sales in H&M stores were below expectations, affected by reduced footfall and imbalances in the assortment composition. It looks like H&M’s product offer has been very sub-optimal this season for what is now a more globally diversified company, and this will need to be addressed for investors to regain faith in H&M longer term.
In particular we think the performance of smaller regional stores has been very poor. To correct this H&M has taken a number of actions including splitting the role of head of the H&M brand, to strengthen the design and buying functions. It is also looking further at optimising the store portfolio with fewer openings and more store closures.
As a result of the weaker sales trend we see potential for more clearance activity in Q4 and particularly Q1. As such we see downside risk to consensus FY17/18 EPS forecasts, prior to today, in the order of 7-14%.

BE12:06pm

The shares are very soft today and we expect them to be lacklustre for a while given the absence of further newsflow until the end of January. We expect further short-term sales disruption from the need to clear excess inventory. However at least in 2018 the currency backdrop is more favourable for H&M both on top line and gross margin and further ecom and property optimization initiatives should enable sales to start to show better trends from the Spring. Post the move lower today valuation is around c.18x CY17 P/E, below the historical average but reflecting recent very tough trends.

This suggested c13% EBITDA growth. It seemed to pull back from this at the last conference call but confirmed that this was delayed last evening.
